SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person submitting this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire in pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience but they may prove impossible for you to answer so don't worry about answering blank spaces. The intention of this form is to secure as much information as possible covering the experiences of the pioneer family, or describe the particular events if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or supply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1 entitled "Pioneer Pictorial History" was distributed to all members of the Saskatchewan Pioneers' Association. It is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 2 entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did We Do?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Glenbow Road,
Saskatoon, Sask.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Nevertheless, there are some questions which are common to all pioneers. The answers to these questions will give us an idea of what pioneer life was like.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Plots: What Did We Answer?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 2, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did We Answer?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the Permanent Records of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

1. Your full name: R. William James Houston

2. Your address: Box 12, Kirby, SASK.

3. Date: May 4th, 1953

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Rapho, Bengal, India

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Andrew A. Houston, Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) March 1905

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (If you do not need to answer this question or you would rather not or you may use "I was in my teens", etc.)

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

Father, mother, two brothers and three sisters came together bought a farm.

In: How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

Through the late W.H. Bryce of Brooks. He was on a visit to Ireland and advised my father to come out and see the West. We came out in 1904 the result was he came home and sold out and came to Canada, the next spring.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Some thought it was a risky undertaking.

12. Did you go by train or by steamship? By train.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Steamship and Railway.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.). Our train was hit from behind sitting in the station at North Bay. One coach was badly derailed but no one was seriously injured.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? I worked for Mr. W. H. Pope for a month then went home as father had told me to.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? East of 5 - 9 - 5 W 8.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you get a living before coming to Western Canada? How old were you?

We all came together. I have a sister and a brother in Winnipeg and a brother at Red Bay on the old farm. Two sisters are deceased.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

The church of Perth was 14 miles which we attended regularly then United Church. We were Presbyterian then.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates where possible.

I was elected to the Council of City of Brock No. 64 in fall of 1930 and have been returned every term since and still hold that office.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "firstly" to have or do something in the district mention it here (skating, taking the first automobile, roadster, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) date in meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in name since then (5) date and reason for change.

Kirby was named for Claud Kirby who drove the mail thru here before the railway came & came to mail thru here before the railway came & was built thru by Arcola in 1900 and in 1904 it was built thru by Regina. The Post Office was at Percy before the railway came. It was named after Percy's church and pioneer of the very early days there was a church and school at Percy.

A daughter Joan married Mrs E R Peterson who lives at Reston now has a son Clare 2 months old. A daughter Andrea married to Donald Harkness and a daughter lives at Kisbey one son John at home also a daughter Marion at home.

Power farming trucks & cars.
